title: Collisions and impulse - cars and spring collide

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A group of students have two carts, Cart <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Cart <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, each of known mass <math alttext="M sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="M sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, respectively. The carts are placed on a straight horizontal track. Cart <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is given an initial speed <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> toward the right. Cart <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is initially at rest and has a spring attached to it, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Cart <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> collides with Cart <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The group of students want to determine the relationship between <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and the fraction of kinetic energy remaining after the collision, which is described by the ratio <math alttext="the fraction with numerator K sub total comma f, end sub, and denominator K sub total comma i, end sub" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mtext>total</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mtext>total</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mfrac></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="K sub total comma f, end sub" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mtext>total</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> is the total kinetic energy of Carts <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> after the collision and <math alttext="K sub total comma i, end sub" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mtext>total</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> is the total kinetic energy of Carts <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> before the collision. (a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to determine if the initial speed of Cart <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> changes the ratio <math alttext="the fraction with numerator K sub total comma f, end sub, and denominator K sub total comma i, end sub" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mtext>total</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mtext>total</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mfrac></mstyle></math>. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

frqParts.text: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A group of students have two carts, Cart <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Cart <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, each of known mass <math alttext="M sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="M sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, respectively. The carts are placed on a straight horizontal track. Cart <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is given an initial speed <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> toward the right. Cart <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is initially at rest and has a spring attached to it, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Cart <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> collides with Cart <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The group of students want to determine the relationship between <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and the fraction of kinetic energy remaining after the collision, which is described by the ratio <math alttext="the fraction with numerator K sub total comma f, end sub, and denominator K sub total comma i, end sub" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mtext>total</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mtext>total</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mfrac></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="K sub total comma f, end sub" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mtext>total</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> is the total kinetic energy of Carts <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> after the collision and <math alttext="K sub total comma i, end sub" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mtext>total</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> is the total kinetic energy of Carts <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> before the collision. (a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to determine if the initial speed of Cart <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> changes the ratio <math alttext="the fraction with numerator K sub total comma f, end sub, and denominator K sub total comma i, end sub" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mtext>total</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mtext>total</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mfrac></mstyle></math>. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) Describe how the collected data should be analyzed to determine whether the value of <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> changes the ratio <math alttext="the fraction with numerator K sub total comma f, end sub, and denominator K sub total comma i, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mtext>total</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mtext>total</mtext><mo>,</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mfrac></mstyle></math>.

In a later experiment, Cart <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is placed at the bottom of a ramp. An impulse device at the bottom of the ramp delivers an impulse to Cart <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> that is directed up the ramp by quickly releasing a burst of high-pressure air, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The magnitude of the impulse delivered to the cart is the same in all trials. Blocks of different known masses can be attached to Cart <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The students are asked to determine the value of the impulse delivered to the block-cart system by the impulse device. The students measure the combined mass <math alttext="M sub 1 comma B, end sub" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>M</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></mstyle></math> of the cart and block. The impulse device delivers the impulse to the block-cart system, and the students measure the maximum vertical height <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi></math> attained by the block-cart system above the initial position of the system. The experiment is repeated using blocks of different masses. The studentsâ€™ measurements are shown in the following table. Trial Number Combined mass of cart and block, <math alttext="M sub 1 comma B, end sub" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></msub></math> <math alttext="(in kilograms)" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>kg</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> Maximum Height <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi></math> <math alttext="(in meters)" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> <math alttext="0.100" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.100</mn></math> <math alttext="0.395" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.395</mn></math> <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> <math alttext="0.150" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.150</mn></math> <math alttext="0.160" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.160</mn></math> <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> <math alttext="0.250" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.250</mn></math> <math alttext="0.070" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.070</mn></math> <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math> <math alttext="0.350" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.350</mn></math> <math alttext="0.035" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.035</mn></math> <math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn></math> <math alttext="0.500" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.500</mn></math> <math alttext="0.015" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.015</mn></math> (c) i. Indicate two quantities that when graphed produces a straight line that could be used to determine a numerical value for the impulse delivered by the impulse device. Use the blank columns in the table to list any calculated quantities you will graph other than the data provided. Vertical Axis:__________ Horizontal Axis:__________
ii. Plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i) on the following graph. Clearly scale and label all axes, including units.
iii. On the above graph, draw a straight line that best represents the data.
(d) Using the straight line from part (c)(iii), calculate the value of the impulse delivered to the cart by the impulse device.

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
